text:
Nigeria’s major export commodities in early years of independence were cocoa (from West), palm oil (from East) and groundnut (from North).

 

The Obasanjo led military administration introduced Operation Feed the Nation to boost food production and Universal Primary Education to enhance school enrolment/literacy level of children 

 

The Aro system in Igbo land was a religious organization 

 

Rate in Nigeria is usually collected by local government 

 

NEPAD was formally adopted on July 11, 2001 in Lusaka Zambia 

 

In 1991 the African Economic Community Treaty was signed in Abuja. The ECOWAS treaty was reviewed in 1991 to make it responsive to new challenges.

 

The first world power that came to the aid of Nigeria during the civil war was defunct USSR.

 

Nigeria relations with African countries are underscored by its policy of Afrocentrism; Africa is the centre piece of Nigeria foreign policy.

 

The foreign policy thrust of the Babangida administration was economic diplomacy (consideration of economic interest) advanced by the then foreign affair minister Ike Nwachukwu Nigeria’s quest for leadership role in Africa hinges on its size and population.

 

In 1986, Nigeria participated in OAU peace keeping force in Chad to replace Libyan force in Chad.

 

The first constitution of Nigeria that provided for the fundamental objectives and directive principles of state policy was the 1979 constitution. 

 

Under the 1999 constitution of Nigeria, the power to create local government is vested on state house of assembly while the Revenue Mobilization 

 

Allocation and Fiscal Commission is empowered to determine remuneration or salaries of political office holders. The appointment and posting of members of election tribunal for the election conducted by INEC is the responsibility of president of the Court of Appeal

 

In Nigeria, the Council of State was first created by General Murtala Mohammed regime

 

Mr. Sam Nujoma of SWAPO was the first President of Namibia. 

 

The six political parties that contested the 1983 general election in Nigeria are NPN, NPP, GNPP, PRP, UPN, NAP; in 1979 election they were five, NAP was not among.

 

The first Pan-African Congress was summoned in 1919 by W.E.B Du-Bois 

 

Lagos Plan of Action was initiated in 1980 to promote Africa economically 

 

Abuja Accord led to the formation of African Economic Commission (AEC) with headquarters in Nairobi, Kenya.

 

Ombudsman (public complaint commission) originated from Sweden in 1809 

 

The philosophy of Zikism, which is a belief in Zik political idea, was propounded by chief Nwafor Orizu but zikist movement was led by Abudllah 

 

The Republic of Yenagoa (unsuccessful) was proclaimed by Issac Adaka Boro 

 

The first former military head of state in Nigeria to be elected as a civilian president was president Olusegun Obasanjo (elected in 1999) while president Mohamadu Buhari was the second (elected in 2015).

 

NAPEP was established in Nigeria in 2001 by President Olusegun Obasanjo’s regime to help in poverty eradication among Nigerians. 

 

The programme, Women for Change Initiative was initiated by Mrs Patience Jonathan during the regime of President Goodluck Jonathan to promote the socio-economic and political empowerment of Nigerian women. 

 

Better Life for Rural Women Programme was set up by Maryam Babangida in 1987 during the regime of president Ibrahim Babangida to promote the socio-economic welfare of rural women.

 

National Accelerated Food Production Programme was established by military government of Yakubu Gowon to boost food production in Nigeria.

 

Green Revolution was an agricultural programme set up by President Shehu Shagari to boost food production.

 

Multi National Joint Task Force with head quarters in N’djamena was established to help in fight against terrorist group within the Chad Base Region. It was formed by members of Lake Chad Basin Commission and Benin Republic. President Mohamadu Buhari was instrumental to the formation of the task force in 2015 following the terror attack of Boko Haram.

 

The Single Treasury Account (TEA) directive by president Muhamadu Buhari was aimed at curbing corruption and promote accountability by ensuring that all federal revenue generated by all government agencies is deposited in single account with Central Bank. 

 

Ethical Revolution was a programme set up by president Shehu Shagari aimed at promoting positive attitude among Nigerians but Change in Nigeria Attitude was a programme instituted by the government of Gen. Aguyi Ironsi.

 

Bi-partisan leadership emerged in the Senate of Nigeria in the 8th session when Bukola Saraki of APC was elected Senate president and Ike Ekweremadu of PDP was elected deputy on June 9lh 2015. 

 

The amalgamation of the Colonies and Protectorate of Lagos and the Southern Nigeria on May 1, 1906 was by Walter Egerton.

 

The amalgamation (based on Selbourn Committee’s recommendation) of the Southern and Northern protectorate and colonies on 1, January 1914 to form Nigeria was by Federick Lugard. 

 

Lagos became Federal Capital Territory of Nigeria in 1954 under Lyttleton constitution. 

 

Federal elections were held in Nigeria in 1954, 1959, 1964, 1979, 1983, 1999, 2003, 2007, 2011 and 2015. 

 

The question/issue about Nigeria civil war was raised for the first time by OAU at the meeting of OAU in Sept. 1967 in Kinshasa, Congo. 

 

Nigeria hosted the meeting of Commonwealth Head of State in 1966. 

 

In 1975, the military government of Mutarla Mohammed set up a committee headed by justice Akinlola Aguda to examine the creation of a new FCT. The committee in 1976 recommended the transfer of FCT from Lagos to Abuja. 

 

 

Burkina Faso was the only French colonized country in West Africa that refused to sign defence pact with France at independence. 

 

Benard Boudillon, a colonial governor, in 1939 divided Nigeria into three provinces while Arthur Richard change the name provinces to regions. 

 

The first international organisation that Nigeria joined immediately after independence was UNO. 

 

The Land Use Decree of 1978 vested ownership of land in Nigeria on state government. 

 

The foreign policy trust under Ibrahim Babangida was economic diplomacy which means that Nigeria will consider its economic benefit in its relation or assistance to any nation.

 

The First General election in Nigeria was held in 1959. 

 

The British Prime Minister who opposed the cancellation of Nigeria’s debt was Margaret Thatcher.

 

The privatization of public corporation or enterprise in Nigeria is the responsibility of Bureau for Private Enterprise.

 

The Berlin Conference of 1884/85 formalized the colonial/imperialist penetration into Africa. 

 

The Sharia legal System was first established in Nigeria (fourth republic) as a state religion in Zamfara state by Governor Ahmed Sani Yerima. 

 

Nigeria played prominent role in OAU/AU during President Olusegun Obasanjo regime. 

 

The foremost British trading company in West Africa was Royal Niger Company. 

 

Charles Taylor, the former President of Liberia was given asylum in Nigeria during the civilian administration of Olusegun Obasanjo. The asylum was aimed at restoring peace in Liberia after Charles Tylor was declared wanted by ICC as result of alleged crime against humanity. His asylum was terminated following his attempt in March 2006 to escape from Nigeria in disguised to avoid being tried at International Criminal Court. 

 

Britain in 2016 in a referendum Voted in favour of withdrawing its membership to European Union. For this reason, the then Prime Minister David Cameron decided to resign because he was against the withdrawal. On July 13, 2016 Theresa May replaced him as the Prime Minister.

 

The first Nigerian Commonwealth Secretary-General was Chief Emeka Anyaoku. The first common wealth secretary-general was Arnold Smith
